@graph.name: How to Inspect Trading Cards for Hidden Defects Before PSA Grading
@graph.description: Step-by-step methodology to detect hidden card defects using proper tools and inspection techniques. This 6-step process takes approximately 15 minutes per card.

tool.name: 10x Jeweler's Loupe
tool.description: Magnification tool for detecting print lines, soft corners, edge chipping, and holo scratches

tool.name: LED Light (5000K)
tool.description: Neutral daylight lighting for accurate color and defect inspection

tool.name: UV Black Light (Optional)
tool.description: Detects PVC damage, UV exposure, and potential restoration

step.name: Environment Setup
step.text: Prepare your inspection workspace with proper tools and lighting. Use a clean, flat surface with bright 5000K LED lighting. Place a dark background cloth for contrast. Put on cotton gloves to prevent fingerprints and oils. Gather all tools: 10x loupe, ruler, and optional UV light.

itemListElement.text: Set up clean, flat work surface
Position 5000K LED light for bright, neutral illumination
Place dark background cloth for edge contrast
Put on cotton gloves to protect card surface

step.name: Naked Eye Inspection
step.text: Perform initial inspection without magnification. Check centering visually—are borders obviously uneven? Examine all four corners for sharpness. Look along each edge for visible chipping or silvering. Check for obvious surface damage, creases, or color fading. If major defects are found, stop and don't submit.

itemListElement.text: Check centering: borders should appear even (measure if uncertain)
Examine corner sharpness: all four should look crisp
Inspect edges for visible damage or whitening
Scan surface for obvious damage or fading

step.name: Magnified Inspection
step.text: Use 10x loupe to detect hidden defects. Hold card at 45-degree angle under bright light and scan for print lines (thin horizontal or vertical lines in solid colors). Angle light across holographic surface and rotate slowly to detect holo scratches. Examine all four corners under magnification for soft corners (rounded vs sharp). Run loupe along all four edges to detect micro-chipping (tiny missing pieces).

itemListElement.text: Scan entire surface with 10x loupe for print lines
Rotate card under angled light to detect holo scratches
Examine all four corners for sharp vs rounded points
Inspect all edges for micro-chipping using loupe

step.name: Angle Lighting Test
step.text: Tilt card under 45-degree angled light to reveal hidden defects. Hold card at eye level and look along each edge for silvering (edge whitening). Slowly rotate card under angled light, watching for surface dent shadows (dark spots indicating indentations). Look for roller marks (parallel indented lines from factory compression). May lightly feel surface with gloved finger to confirm texture variations.

itemListElement.text: Hold card at eye level under angled light
Check all four edges for silvering (white areas)
Rotate slowly to detect surface dent shadows
Look for parallel roller marks across surface

step.name: Black Light Test (Optional)
step.text: If you have a UV black light, use it to detect chemical damage and UV exposure. Shine UV light on card surface and look for uneven fluorescence indicating PVC damage from poor storage. Check for faded areas that may show differently under UV (sun damage). Look for restoration indicators (re-colored edges or surface alterations may fluoresce). Compare to a known clean card for reference.

itemListElement.text: Shine UV black light on card surface
Look for uneven fluorescence (PVC damage)
Check for UV exposure damage patterns
Compare to clean reference card

step.name: Documentation & Decision
step.text: Record your findings and make a submission decision. Photo any defects found for reference or expert consultation. Predict grade based on defects: zero defects = submit for PSA 10, one minor defect = submit for PSA 9 (if value justifies), multiple defects = hold. Perform cost-benefit analysis: calculate PSA 10 value, PSA 9 value, grading fee, and determine if submission is worthwhile.

itemListElement.text: Photo any defects for documentation
Predict grade: PSA 10, 9, 8, or hold
Calculate cost vs benefit of submission
Make final decision: submit or hold

mainEntity.name: What are the most common hidden defects in PSA grading?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most common hidden defects that prevent PSA 10 grades are: 1) Print lines (40% of rejections) - Factory defects visible under magnification, 2) Silvering (30%) - Edge whitening from handling or storage, 3) Holo scratches (20%) - Surface scratches on holographic foil, and 4) Soft corners (5-10%) - Rounded corners from manufacturing. These defects are 'hidden' because they require magnification (10x loupe), specific lighting angles, or proper tools to detect.

mainEntity.name: How can I spot print lines on Pokemon cards?

acceptedAnswer.text: To spot print lines: 1) Use a 10x jeweler's loupe ($10-20 investment), 2) Hold the card at a 45-degree angle under bright LED light (5000K recommended), 3) Scan the entire surface, paying attention to solid color areas, borders, and text boxes, 4) Look for thin, consistent lines (horizontal or vertical) across the surface, 5) Rotate the card slowly - print lines may only be visible at certain angles. Common locations include card borders, holographic patterns, and solid background colors. Print lines are factory defects and account for approximately 40% of PSA 10 rejections.

mainEntity.name: What is silvering in card grading?

acceptedAnswer.text: Silvering is edge whitening caused by handling, storage, or manufacturing. It appears as white or light-colored areas along the card edge where the colored ink layer has worn away or separated from the card stock. To detect: 1) Place card on a dark background, 2) Examine all four edges under bright light, 3) Hold the card at eye level and look along each edge, 4) Check both front and back edges. PSA Stance: Zero tolerance for visible silvering on PSA 10. Even minor edge whitening on a single edge will prevent Gem Mint 10 grade. Silvering accounts for approximately 30% of PSA 10 rejections.

mainEntity.name: Can I fix card defects before PSA submission?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. PSA prohibits any alteration or restoration. Attempting to fix defects (pressing, coloring edges, trimming, cleaning with chemicals, or any surface alterations) will result in: card rejection, loss of grading fees, potential ban from PSA services, and 'Altered' designation on the card. If your card has defects, you should submit with accurate grade expectations, hold the card, or use professional pre-grade evaluation to determine if submission is worthwhile.

mainEntity.name: What tools do I need to inspect cards for grading?

acceptedAnswer.text: Essential tools ($30-70 total): 1) 10x Jeweler's Loupe ($10-20) - Detects print lines, holo scratches, soft corners, edge chipping, 2) 5000K LED Light Source ($15-30) - Provides neutral daylight lighting for accurate inspection, 3) Cotton Gloves ($5) - Prevents fingerprints and oils during handling, 4) Ruler or Digital Calipers ($5-15) - Measures centering (55/45 front, 75/25 back tolerance). Optional: 5) UV Black Light ($10-20) - Detects PVC damage, UV exposure, potential restoration, 6) Dark Background Cloth ($5) - Black microfiber for contrast when checking edges. ROI: These tools pay for themselves after preventing one bad submission ($50-300 grading fee saved).

mainEntity.name: What's the difference between soft corners and hard corners?

acceptedAnswer.text: Soft corners are rounded with no sharp point, caused by manufacturing defect, usually have no whitening, and result in PSA 9 or lower. Hard corners are crisp with sharp 90-degree angles, from proper factory cut, have no whitening, and are PSA 10 eligible if no other defects exist. To check: 1) Examine each corner under 10x magnification, 2) Look for a sharp point vs rounded softness, 3) Compare to a reference card with known sharp corners. All four corners must be sharp for PSA 10. Frustration factor: High - Card can be pack-fresh yet have soft corners preventing PSA 10.

mainEntity.name: How strict is PSA on factory defects vs handling damage?

acceptedAnswer.text: PSA treats factory defects and handling damage equally for PSA 10 consideration. PSA's official stance: 'A Gem Mint 10 is virtually perfect. An allowance can be made for a slight printing imperfection, so long as it doesn't impair the overall appeal of the card.' In practice: Minor factory defects (very faint print lines not visible from 16 inches) may be allowed, but this is rare. Moderate factory defects (visible print lines, roller marks, soft corners) result in PSA 9 or lower. Handling damage (holo scratches, silvering, edge chipping) results in PSA 9 or lower. Bottom line: Don't assume factory defects get special treatment. If the defect is visible under PSA's magnified inspection, it will likely prevent PSA 10, regardless of cause.

mainEntity.name: Should I submit my card if I find a hidden defect?

acceptedAnswer.text: It depends on: 1) Defect Severity - Very minor (light print line, one slightly soft corner) = Submit for PSA 9 if value justifies; Moderate (visible silvering, multiple defects) = Hold; Severe (heavy scratches, poor centering) = Don't submit. 2) Card Value - PSA 9 value > $100 = Consider submitting (authentication + grade value); PSA 9 value < $100 = Likely not worth grading fee ($50-150). 3) Personal Goals - Investment: Only submit if PSA 9+ value justifies cost; Personal collection: Grade for authentication and preservation. Decision Matrix: Zero defects + high value = Submit for PSA 10; One minor defect + medium value = Submit for PSA 9; Multiple defects or low value = Hold; Uncertain about severity = Get professional pre-grade evaluation.

mainEntity.name: What is centering tolerance for PSA 10?

acceptedAnswer.text: PSA 10 centering requirements: Front = 55/45 to 60/40 (maximum), Back = 75/25 (maximum). How to measure: 1) Measure border widths on opposite sides (left vs right, top vs bottom), 2) Calculate the ratio: smaller ÷ larger, 3) Convert to percentage. Example: Left border 2.5mm, Right border 3mm → Ratio: 2.5 ÷ 3 = 0.833 → Approximately 55/45 (Passes). Both left/right AND top/bottom must meet tolerance. PSA Grading Tiers: PSA 10: 60/40 max (front), 75/25 max (back); PSA 9: 70/30 max (front), 90/10 max (back); PSA 8: 75/25 max (front), 90/10 max (back).

mainEntity.name: Can hidden defects be seen in regular photos?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. Hidden defects cannot be reliably detected in regular photos because they require: 1) Magnification (10x loupe) - Photos lack this detail, 2) Specific lighting angles (45-degree angled light) - Photos use flat lighting, 3) Physical inspection (feeling for dents, rotating for holo scratches) - Photos are static. What photos MISS: Print lines (too subtle for camera), Micro-chipping (too small to photograph), Soft corners (need magnification to distinguish from sharp), Light silvering (camera flash washes it out), Surface dents (need angled light to create shadows). This is why in-person inspection with proper tools is critical before submission. Exception: High-resolution macro photography with professional lighting may capture some defects, but still misses many that PSA's in-person inspection will catch.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Print Lines

hasDefinedTerm.description: Surface scratches on holographic foil treatment, visible under angled light

hasDefinedTerm.name: Soft Corners
hasDefinedTerm.description: Rounded corners from manufacturing defect rather than sharp 90-degree angles

hasDefinedTerm.name: Centering Issues
hasDefinedTerm.description: Card image positioning outside PSA 10 tolerance (Front: 60/40 max, Back: 75/25 max)

hasDefinedTerm.name: Roller Marks
hasDefinedTerm.description: Indentations from factory printing rollers compressing card during production

hasDefinedTerm.name: Surface Dents
hasDefinedTerm.description: Small indentations in card surface from pressure or impact, visible under angled light

hasDefinedTerm.name: Edge Chipping
hasDefinedTerm.description: Small chips or missing pieces along card edge, requires 10x magnification to detect micro-chips

hasDefinedTerm.name: Color Fading/Bleeding
hasDefinedTerm.description: Washed out colors (fading) or ink spreading beyond boundaries (bleeding) from print quality or UV damage

hasDefinedTerm.name: PVC Damage
hasDefinedTerm.description: Chemical damage from polyvinyl chloride in cheap sleeves, appears as hazy, sticky surface
